TextView.android:text: Irises are perennial flowering plants of the genus Iris in the family Iridaceae, comprising over 300 species with a wide variety of colors and forms. They are known for their distinctive, showy flowers, which typically have three upright petals (standards) and three downward sepals (falls), often marked with contrasting colors or intricate patterns. Native to temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere, irises are commonly found in Europe, Asia, and North America, thriving in a range of habitats from meadows to wetlands. The leaves are usually narrow, sword-shaped, and grow in a fan-like arrangement from the base, ranging from 30 to 90 cm in length. Irises grow from either rhizomes or bulbs, depending on the species, and produce tall, erect flowering stalks that may bear one or multiple blooms. The flowers are often blue, purple, white, yellow, or bi-colored, and many species are cultivated for ornamental use in gardens and floral arrangements. Irises symbolize wisdom, courage, and hope, and are notable in art and culture, particularly in ancient Greek mythology and French heraldry.
